org.gearvrf

Class GVRMaterial

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRShaderData
        • org.gearvrf.GVRMaterial
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    GVRConsole

    public class GVRMaterial
extends GVRShaderData
    Encapculates data to be sent to a vertex or fragment shader. It contains a list of key / value pairs which can specify arbitrary length float or int vectors. It also has key / value pairs for the texture samplers to be used with the shader.

    Visible scene objects must have render data GVRSceneObject.attachRenderData(GVRRenderData) attached. Each GVRRenderData has a GVRMesh that defines its geometry, and a GVRMaterial that defines its surface.

    Each GVRMaterial contains two main things:

    • The id of a shader, which is used to draw the mesh. See GVRMaterial.GVRShaderType and GVRContext.getMaterialShaderManager().
    • Data to pass to the shader. This usually - but not always - means a GVRTexture and can include other named values to pass to the shader.

    The simplest way to create a GVRMaterial is to call the GVRMaterial(GVRContext) constructor that takes only a GVRContext. Then you just GVRShaderData.setTexture(String, GVRTexture) and you're ready to draw with the default shader, which is called 'unlit' because it simply drapes the texture over the mesh, without any lighting or reflection effects. 

     
 // for example
 GVRMaterial material = new GVRMaterial(gvrContext);
 material.setTexture("u_texture", texture);
 }

      • getMainTexture

        public GVRTexture getMainTexture()

        Returns:
        The main texture

        lightMapInformation - Atlas information object with the offset and scale at UV space necessary to map the light map texture to the mesh.

      • setTextureAtlasInfo

                                GVRAtlasInformation atlasInformation)
        Set the light map information(offset and scale) at UV space to map the light map texture to the mesh.
        Parameters:
        key - Prefix name of the uniform at light map shader: ([key]_texture, [key]_offset and [key]_scale.
        atlasInformation - Atlas information object with the offset and scale at UV space necessary to map the light map texture to the mesh.

      • setTextureAtlasInfo

        public void setTextureAtlasInfo(java.lang.String key,
                                float[] offset,
                                float[] scale)
        Set the light map information(offset and scale) at UV space to map the light map texture to the mesh.
        Parameters:
        key - Prefix name of the uniform at light map shader: ([key]_texture, [key]_offset and [key]_scale.
        offset - Array with x and y offset values at UV space to map the 2D texture to the mesh.
        scale - Array with x and y scale values at UV space to map the 2D texture to the mesh.

      • getColor

        public float[] getColor()
        Get the u_color uniform. By convention, some of the GVRF shaders can use a vec3 uniform named u_color. With the default 'texture' shader, this allows you to modulate the texture with a color.
        Returns:
        The current vec3 u_color as a three-element array

      • getRgbColor

        public int getRgbColor()
        A convenience method that wraps getColor() and returns an Android GVRMaterial.GVRShaderType.Color
        Returns:
        An Android GVRMaterial.GVRShaderType.Color

      • setColor

        public void setColor(float r,
                     float g,
                     float b)
        Set the u_color uniform. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a vec3 uniform named color. With the default 'texture' shader, this allows you to modulate the texture with a color. Values are between 0.0f and 1.0f, inclusive.
        Parameters:
        r - Red
        g - Green
        b - Blue

      • setColor

        public void setColor(int color)
        A convenience overload of setColor(float, float, float) that lets you use familiar Android GVRMaterial.GVRShaderType.Color values.
        Parameters:
        color - Any Android GVRMaterial.GVRShaderType.Color; the alpha byte is ignored.

      • getAmbientColor

        public float[] getAmbientColor()
        Get the ambient_color uniform. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a vec4 uniform named ambient_color. With the default 'texture' shader, this allows you to modulate the texture with a color.
        Returns:
        The current vec4 ambient_color as a four-element array

      • setAmbientColor

        public void setAmbientColor(float r,
                            float g,
                            float b,
                            float a)
        Set the ambient_color uniform for lighting. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a vec4 uniform named ambient_color. With the shader, this allows you to add an overlay ambient light color on top of the texture. Values are between 0.0f and 1.0f, inclusive.
        Parameters:
        r - Red
        g - Green
        b - Blue
        a - Alpha

      • getDiffuseColor

        public float[] getDiffuseColor()
        Get the diffuse_color uniform. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a vec4 uniform named diffuse_color. With the shader, this allows you to add an overlay color on top of the texture.
        Returns:
        The current vec4 diffuse_color as a four-element array

      • getSpecularExponent

        public float getSpecularExponent()
        Get the specular_exponent uniform. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a float uniform named specular_exponent. With the shader, this allows you to add an overlay color on top of the texture.
        Returns:
        The current float specular_exponent as a float value.

      • setSpecularExponent

        public void setSpecularExponent(float exp)
        Set the specular_exponent uniform for lighting. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a float uniform named specular_exponent. With the shader, this allows you to add an overlay specular light color on top of the texture. Values are between 0.0f and 128.0f, inclusive.
        Parameters:
        exp - Specular exponent

      • getOpacity

        public float getOpacity()
        Get the u_opacity uniform.

        The setOpacity() documentation explains what the u_opacity uniform does.

        Returns:
        The u_opacity uniform used to render this material

      • setOpacity

        public void setOpacity(float opacity)
        Set the opacity (u_opacity uniform), in a complicated way. There are two things you need to know, how opacity is applied, and how opacity is implemented.

        First, GVRF does not sort by distance every object it can see, then draw from back to front. Rather, it sorts every object by render order, then draws the scene graph in traversal order. So, if you want to see a scene object through another scene object, you have to explicitly set the rendering order so that the translucent object draws after the opaque object. You can use any integer values you like, but GVRF supplies four standard values; the default value is GEOMETRY.

        Second, technically all this method does is set the opacity uniform. What this does depends on the actual shader. If you don't specify a shader (or you specify the GVRMaterial.GVRShaderType.Texture shader) setting u_opacity does exactly what you expect; you only have to worry about the render order. However, it is totally up to a custom shader whether or how it will handle opacity.

        Parameters:
        opacity - Value between 0.0f and 1.0f, inclusive.

      • getLineWidth

        public float getLineWidth()
        Gets the line width for line drawing.
        See Also:
        GVRRenderData.setDrawMode(int)

      • setLineWidth

        public void setLineWidth(float lineWidth)
        Sets the line width for line drawing. By default, the line width is 1. It is applied when the draw mode is GL_LINES, GL_LINE_STRIP or GL_LINE_LOOP.
        Parameters:
        lineWidth - new line width.
        See Also:
        GVRRenderData.setDrawMode(int)
